utterances: Well, best of luck to you, Mr. Thatcher.
Okay.
That's Tony Thatcher, a citrus farmer battling the big freeze in Ohigh, California.
I'm joined now by a member of one of the Iraq Study Group's four internal working groups.
Larry Diamond is a senior fellow at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, and he's a former adviser to the Coalition Provisional Authority in Iraq.
And Larry Diamond, welcome to the program.
Nice to be with you.
At this point can you tell us what the major proposals are under consideration by the Iraq Study Group?
What is - what's on the table?
No. The understanding that we all have is that the internal deliberations of the Iraq Study Group are confidential.
What I can say is that there's a very healthy diversity of opinion among the members of the expert working groups.
And the members themselves have listened very carefully, but I think have been extremely wise and discreet in not tipping their own hand.
We have heard a few ideas, though, that have been leaked out by James Baker, in fact, that Iran and Syria might be brought in.
Can you give us some sort of broad ideas like that one?
Well Baker has indicated that maybe it's going to be necessary to talk to our enemies.
He was speaking for himself, not the commission.
And he was speaking speculatively.
And in any case many people believe, and I am certainly one of them, that Syria has significant influence over the Sunni-based insurgency.
In fact it now increasingly appears that Syria is intensely funding and equipping it with weapons.
And Iran has significant influence with the Shiite-based militias, many of whom have formed ferocious death squads that are responsible for much of the recent violence.
So, you know, it's not like these countries have a switch that they can simply turn on or off.
Neither is it likely to be the case that with a little bit of dialogue they would exert pressure.
But Iraq is increasingly a regional problem, and I would even say an international problem.
And if you only try to pursue it internally, and only with American diplomatic mediation, it's almost certainly not going to work.
Another idea that Baker has reportedly talked about is settling the Israeli-Palestinian conflict as part of the solution to Iraq.
What do you think of that?
Well I think if the goal is to settle the Israeli-Palestinian conflict then we could be waiting for a very long time.
But let me phrase it slightly differently.
In a context where the United States is actively pursuing Middle East peace then other things can happen, and America's reputation in the region tends to rise.
In a conflict where there's no discussion, no active American mediation efforts, things tend to deteriorate.
That's a lesson Baker learned himself from his own period as secretary of state.

And so, resuming a process of dialogue and negotiation, and perhaps at least some interim concessions on each side, could create a momentum toward peace in the entire region - rather than the momentum toward violent conflict that we have had, which has only strengthened and emboldened the extremists on all sides.

Given what we've just been talking about, about talking with our so-called enemies - Syria and Iran, and putting the Israeli-Palestinian conflict on the front burner - do you think that the Iraq Study Group's recommendations will end up being a fairly strong repudiation of the Bush administration's foreign policy?
No.
Certainly not explicitly.
I think that the Iraq Study Group is going to want to have impact.
So my guess is they're not going to deliver, you know, an analytic, rhetorical assessment.
I think their goal is a very practical one.

It's not to engage in recriminations about what's happened in the past but to figure out how to stabilize and repair a very grave situation in terms of American engagement in Iraq and how to create a context in which the United States at some point -you know, in the next period of time, whether it's a year or three years or four years or whatever - how the United States could responsibly withdraw.
Larry Diamond is a member of one of the expert working groups advising the Iraq Study Group.
Larry Diamond, thank you for joining us.
It's been a pleasure.
(Soundbite of music)
We've been talking about the government shutdown which comes on the anniversary of Donald Trump's inauguration as president.
Thousands of people took to the streets today as they did a year ago in women's marches in cities like New York, Houston, Chicago, Denver, Los Angeles and here in Washington, D.C.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(As Bell) Hey, you like eggnog?
OK.
So we've got starlings.
We also have a book here called ""The Trouble With Goats And Sheep."" What on earth is the trouble with goats and sheep?
Well, I can't tell you that exactly 'cause that might give away too much.
But what I can tell you is this is a fabulous first novel by Joanna Cannon, set in 1976 in a small village in England.
It's one of the hottest summers on record there, and one of the women in this neighborhood has disappeared.
Mrs. Creasy is nowhere to be found, and no one knows where she's gone.
And two little girls, Tilly and Grace, decide they are going to find out what happened to Mrs. Creasy.

So this is a little bit of a mystery, but more, it's an examination of a group of people all with secrets of their own and the fear that some of those secrets are going to come out because of the girls' inquisitiveness.

But it's laced with the absolute just wonderful, wonderful touches of humor, including an absolutely priceless scene when Tilly and Grace make one of their regular trips to the library and are looking for something good to read.
I loved this book.
So we've got a book here called ""1947: Where Now Begins.
This is exactly the kind of history that I love to read.
What Elisabeth Asbrink has done is take one particular year, 1947, two years after the end of World War II, and go through month by month talking about everything that happened during those months.
And the book is interwoven with her father's story, who spent 1947 in an orphanage in Germany, and his experiences.
So there's so much in here.

I mean, it's one of those books that I kept marking it up with bookmarks that the book kind of grew to twice its normal size because there was all these notes that I took, and I mean, it's just one of those books that makes you want to major in history.
You know?
It just is the best nonfiction book that I've read recently.
Wow.
Yes.
So so Louisa Luna is the author of a novel that you've got on this stack that you sent me, ""Two Girls Down.
I picked this one up because I'm always looking for a good thriller.
The two main characters, one of them is a bounty hunter named Alice Vega, lives in California, but she's called to come to a small town in Pennsylvania where two sisters have been kidnapped.
And she has had great success in finding missing children before.
And she goes to work with a disgraced policeman from the town's police force.
And the two of them together make this very interesting team, bringing their separate talents together to try to locate these two girls.
My favorite part of your description is you say a bounty hunter named - and the mind naturally is expecting a male name.
That's a stereotypically male character.
But then you say a bounty hunter named Alice Vega.
So she went a different direction here.
And that's really interesting.
Correct.
Does ""Seven-Day Magic"" have a strong dragon character in it?
(Laughter).
I guess we should explain.
There's a book here, ""Seven-Day Magic,"" by Edward Eager.
So there are two kinds of fantasy for children, and the one that has taken precedence is the type of fantasy where there's a magic world, where magic occurs in the world.
Everybody knows that.
So, you know, the ""Harry Potter"" books are the best example of that.
Sure.

But in the 20th century, the big kind of fantasy were books in which ordinary boys and girls find something that's magic and they have to, as you learn when you read this book, you find the magic, you tame the magic and then you use the magic.
But I especially wanted to talk about this one because it's about a magic book, and these five children go to the library.
They see this book just lying on the shelf.
It doesn't have a nice cover.
It looks very worn.
When they check it out, the librarian gives them a very interested look.
It's only a seven-day book.
And what we do is follow seven days of what happens to them as they gradually use the magic in the book.
Fabulous.
So a magic book.
This is pretty much a metaphor for your whole life as a librarian?
(Laughter).
It is.
It absolutely is because there's a great line in this book.
Every time somebody different holds the book, it becomes exactly the kind of book that they want to read.
Isn't that wonderful?
Nancy, thanks for sending these book recommendations to us.
Really appreciate it.
My pleasure, Steve.
Summer reading from Nancy Pearl, who's a librarian and also a novelist, the author of ""George And Lizzie: A Novel."" And you can find all of her recommendations at npr.org.
For the rest of the hour, Joseph Priestley.
Around three million years ago, the first photosynthetic organisms began to belch oxygen into Earth's atmosphere.
Well, let's fast forward to 1772 and a makeshift home laboratory in Leeds, England.
Joseph Priestley, a radical preacher and science hobbyist, puts a mouse and sprig of mint in an underwater jar and discovers that plants somehow recharge and refresh our breathable air.
